Description: Rim and body fragment of Attic black-figured pottery olpe, mended from several fragments; interior: glazed black at rim, reserved below; exterior: glazed black save for panel which has black-figure decoration consisting of ram to right with added red on muzzle, alternating sections of horn, neck, ribs, stomach, scrotum, and upper part of far foreleg; hanging hooks and rosettes.
Producer name: Attributed to the Manner of: The Gorgon Painter ((Venit))
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Sanctuary of Aphrodite (Naukratis), Context Φ3, Φ4 or Φ7.
Curator's comments: The handle and foot are modern. Beazley and Payne point to the early character of the filling ornament. For parallels regarding the ornament below the ram’s neck, compare British Museum 1874,0410.1. For the worm-like lines adhering to the border, compare Athens, Acropolis Museum 364 in Graef, B. and Langlotz, E., Die antiken Vasen von der Akropolis zu Athens. Berlin 1925-33, pl. 13. 364. See Venit 1984, 142 for a discussion of early features.
Bibliographic references: Beazley & Payne 1929 / Attic Black Figured Fragments from Naukratis (p. 253, no. 1)
Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 298, no. B288)
Venit 1984 / Early Attic Black Figure Vases in Egypt (p. 142)
Möller 2000 / Naukratis, Trade in Archaic Greece (p. 223, no. 3)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0283) (Phase 1)
Gardner 1888 / Naukratis II (p. 43, pl. IX, no. 5)
